pros: Talented, inclusive workforce, true meritocracy. Ive worked for like four teams over the course of my eight years at IBM. I can remember exactly 2 people that were not great to work with. IBM from my experience, encourages creativity, values the individual, and promotes team cohesion. Sure I would rather make six figures selling umbrella drinks at a tiki bar, but this is unlikely. I have no plans of leaving IBM and see only growth both for me and the company. They are really making amazing strides in AI, Cloud, Cybersecurity, and I kinda want to have some small part of this success.
cons: BIG company that entered the Cloud space fairly late compared to AWS, Google, etc. Sometimes old patterns of thinking have to be challenged, that would not even exist in a smaller, newer company. That said, IBM has made big moves in adopting agile practices. Another con is that this is a VERY big pond, so if you want to get recognized for your contributions, just make sure you are working in an area that the C levels really care about. If what you LOVE to do is just something that is considered an unfortunate necessity of business, then it is unlikely you can make a big splash. I have found it easy to share these concerns with my management and was pleasantly surprised when I was engaged in more high visibility opportunities. But of course, then you have to really perform!

job_title: Applications Developer in Helsinki, Southern Finland
pros:
The best part are definitely the people. We have somehow succeeded very well there - I've met only one person that didn't treat colleagues well (she is not working here anymore). The recruitment process (for me) was casual and didn't have any impossible Google-like puzzles to solve (you get only one type of people with that kind of recruiting, not good for diversity). 

The salary is good and stable (smaller consulting companies with commission based pay may have better salary if you work on a project full time). The work is interesting and it is possible to change job descriptions if you wish. Career progression is encouraged and guided. Learning is encouraged (some even mandatory, like one certification per year - no cost to the employee of course). There are some after-hours clubs around sports, games, theater etc.
cons:
If people were the best thing, then layoffs or corporate negotiations are the worst. There have been two since I started, but it seems we are on the right track again and hopefully no more will come for a long time. 

Processes can be a bit stiff, but I don't have to deal much with them in my job (depends on the job role of course).

review_title: Good company to start career with
job_title: Advisory Software Engineer in Durham, NC
pros:
- Leadership development, mentoring and personal growth. This was a good place to start my career, so many talented individuals able to work with and learn from. 
- Culture of working remotely even before COVID. Fortunate able to work with a good team and good management for years that fostered this + work-life balance.
- Opportunity to work on patents / intellectual property in any job role. Come up with the idea, IBM will take care of the rest + reward financially.
cons:
- Constant axe hanging over your head, never know if you'll have a job tomorrow due to layoffs, no matter your individual performance.
- Risk adverse. IBM prefers to buy instead of build their own. I've witnessed first hand a business proposal for a new amazing idea (containizeration in its earliest days - before Kubernetes existed) get rejected. IBM purchased Red Hat to catchup vs. take the risk internally to develop the idea. Many other examples similar to this observed over the years.
- Financial based decision making. Short term thinking at expense of long term investment. Poor bonuses due to impossible to meet company goals, frequent attrition (both voluntary and involuntary), missed strategic opportunities, etc. results from this.

review_title: Magical in most places, but stagnant in a few core areas.
job_title: Senior Managing Consultant in London, England
pros:
I for one find IBM's brand undeniably cool. It's difficult to not be inspired by the fleet of Quantum computers, IBM Design Language, what we do at the US Open etc. This all of course helps get a conversation with a client. IBM does a very good job (in my view) of being inclusive and encouraging cross-department interactions, so you actually can get exposed to this cool stuff, learn and direct your career based on curiosity... to an extent.

On the people side, I can only speak about my industry team and practice, but they a great group of people with a healthy and supportive attitude. HR guidance does feel like it translates to day-to-day culture. The learning syllabus and training opportunities are also top notch.
cons: The magical stuff above does exist, but is ultimately restricted to occasional enjoyment. It doesn't crystalise to truly innovative work or radical thinking. Why? That takes conviction and upsets impatient shareholders. It also needs years of investment, patience and a tolerance for failure. In reality practitioners time and attention is dictated by quarterly dividends and monthly operational targets. It is difficult for the company to free itself from the reactive mindset associated with a listed company.

review_title: Can be okay, can be terrible. Wage compression a big issue
pros:
- Free training
- Good benefits (health, dental, pension)
- Nice office environment
- More positive experiences with coworkers than negative.
- Some good projects out there
cons:
- Low pay for the type of work (45k a year for software engineer is abysmal)
- Some projects force you, and others pressure you: to work 7 days a week; this is illegal, and should be investigated.
- Managers have very little power, and absolutely no say in what employees make.
- When I started there in 2021, all new hires were making 45k, but anyone hired on in 2022 is making 50k, BUT they did NOT adjust salaries accordingly to keep up with inflation.
- Very long probation period (9 months)
- No overtime pay for extra work.
- Very long bench period (4 months), and even after that I was just thrown at random projects - they don't really use your skillset, they just put you where they need you, even if it's with technology you never used.

I want to share this for the only educational purposes, be it be with IBM management or people seeing them self work for IBM. 

1. IBM is filled with old mindset driven people, people with 20+ years of experience and absalet skills. You can't expect any kind of professionalism from them be it with the way the talk(you feel like your talking with your high school principal) and they will call you on your personal number any time and for every stupid reason.


2. They have no clue on what needs to be done and are hiring people do things without any roadmap. These people are expected to 13 hours for a deliverables which will always miss the deadline as there is no clue on what needs to be no concept of POC. Lead by really unacknowledged management.

3. If you want to learn and expand your skill set and expect a professional treatment please stay away from IBM it far better to work with smaller company and for less money as if will contribute something to your future. 

4. Hike is a joke here. People who are part of this company for more than 6 years got hike only twice,that to single digit. One more instance, team mate who worked 18 hours a day was not given hike for a years and next years they gave 3 % and no concept of shift allowance you can't claim your OT.

5. Worst company i worked with in my professional experience.

review_title: Excellent company to explore growth areas as employee is supported with world class learning.
pros: While working with IBM, you can explore newer growth areas and roles. In my 14 years in IBM I was fortunate to get different roles and could work with different industry leading customers. This helped me to shape my career and gain valuable experience and insight. I never felt i was working for only one company. And I am very grateful for IBM to give me international assignments and challenging roles to build me into a well rounded professional. I could enroll for training and certifications of my choice and got complete support from my managers to pursue my aspirations. There is no discrimination in offering technical certification. I love this about working here. The leadership, technical and domain learning available in IBM are world class, gold standard training. There is something for everyone here.
cons: Working for IBM has few cons, one is the difference of the working style in India compared to when i was on an international assignment. Working late hours are common when you are serving customers from North Americas and Europe. Its expected by default. And taking vacations even when you have remaining vacations days has been a struggle as everyone has to achieve a high utilization percentage. Which you cannot achieve if you take all your allocated leaves.

job_title: Learning Strategist in Helsinki, Southern Finland
pros:
I have thoroughly enjoyed my ride with the big blue for over two decades now. So, clearly there has to be a number of great reasons for me staying committed with this company. 
Couple of key things that I appreciate about IBM:
- I have had various job roles throughout my career from Project Manager to First line manager to Learning & Knowledge roles both within my own country and outside. A good company provides opportunities for growth. I would imagine that in a smaller company opportunities for different job roles and working in different countries are more limited.
- My expertise is in IT. If I was working for a company outside IT, I would undoubtedly end up in a supporting role. In IBM I'm directly impacting the bottom line. 
- I highly value the opportunities and empowerment for continuous learning. 
- I feel a deep sense of pride as IBM has been taking an firm stand for gender, racial, sexual and other equality and embracing diversity for over 100 years! 
- I also respect the focus on open standards when it comes to technologies since the early days of Linux and Java and extending to these days of hybrid multi cloud.
- There are absolutely great people in IBM. I have forged many personal relationships over the years -- I imagine this to be true to many other companies though.
cons: Being a massive company comes with some level of inescapable level of bureaucratic processes. Coming from a small company background before joining IBM, I still find more positives and than negatives.

review_title: Continuous transformation leads to low employee morale
pros: IBM is a place that truly values career development and learning. There's great work/life balance. All managers & coworkers are supportive of exploring career options in the company and helping you reach your goals. You'll learn a lot and it's a great place to start a career. As an entry level employee, I had access to senior level executives and am forever appreciative of what I learned from those experiences. The people who work here are smart, friendly and patient in teaching you new things to watch you grow. I'm grateful for all the people I worked with and had as mentors at IBM and will be rooting from afar. IBM is also a company that truly values D&I and deploying tech for good (although there's always room for improvement!).
cons:
Compensation could be improved, compared to others in the industry. Notoriously overly complex internal structure and very bureaucratic. IBM is also undergoing extensive internal transformation (as it should) to get back to sustainable growth. I have faith in leaders like Arvind and Rob Thomas, but there has been so much change, it's hard to execute on strategy when things are changing every 6 months. 

Most notably, the newest CMO doesn't know what she's doing. No clarity on how to execute on new strategy. Absolute mess. Everyone is leaving left and right due to low morale and no direction from senior leadership. She's got to go.

pros: Good Work Culture, Flexible timing

job_title: Data Center Facilities Manager in Boulder, CO
pros: IBM was a fantastic place to work, with a great work-life balance. My management and leadership were always tremendously supportive and recognized the contributions of the team. I enjoyed my time there. I was outsourced with a change in corporate strategy which led to a spin-off of their GTS division to Kyndryl.
cons:
Raises and bonuses were meager, though the compensation and benefits for everyone was fair. The only way to get significant raises there was through promotion, which I was fortunate to have achieved. Unfortunately, this could not be the case for everyone.

As it was a mature company with no growth in that segment, we were all just waiting for people to retire so we could clamor for their jobs. Many times those promotional opportunities evaporated when the organization restructured to eliminate the job after their retirement. 

The end result was that promising young engineers with other opportunities left the company. People with little other opportunity or high risk aversion stayed around, and company performance continued to slow.

Many times the corporate culture and process were extremely bureaucratic and focused on cost-cutting to the long term detriment of morale and business agility. The company continued to centralize so much spending authority to finance over the years that it became very difficult to maintain the facilities, which ended up deteriorating.

review_title: IBM is a highly inclusive place to learn, grow and feel empowered
pros:
From a learning point of view you can have access to outstanding learning content on any topic you may look for : "Your Learning" is like an internal "Wikipedia" and you can choose the knowledge and skills you want to learn and improve. It can be delivered on-line, face to face, in virtual classes or practices and role play. Actually IBM encourages you to invest at least 40 hours in learning as a minimum every year and even more if you want.

From a personal development point of view you feel then empowered to take initiatives, calculated risks and to define yourself with IBM's support your career path !
In 20 years of service I have got 4 different jobs (consultant, seller, buyer, trainer) and worked in many locations around the world. Very few companies can offer this to a professional !

Inclusion culture is lived at heart : IBM is one of the best place to work globally with an incredible team representing all human diversity of cultures, personal beliefs and choices. Most importantly IBMers share core values about respect, team work and fair relationship.
cons:
As IBM transforms itself to become more agile and client's centric, most of the "cons" are currently being removed. 
Of course there is still room for improvement about giving everybody a clear view about the way forward and how to individually contribute to IBM's transformation.

cons:
-Sooner or later you will be part of a layoff. 
-IBM is well known for taking really bad decisions at the executive level, which in the end affects their workforce. This is why there are layoffs every year
-I had to fire my entire team (20+ members) 2 times in less the 8 years.
-Not a place to be. Culture sucks and upper management does not care about employees. 
-Senior Management takes all the credit for his subordinates. 
-The 80/20 rule is 100% true at IBM. Only 20% of employees do 80% of the work. This is why there is no work-life balance at IBM. 
-I was part of this 20% for around 10 years, but I decided to quit. It is not affordable in the long term.
-Salary is really low at IBM compared to the market.
-Benefits are a joke

review_title: Great place to work but needs to pay more
pros:
IBM is a wonderful place to work, I can say this very clearly.
You become like a family with your teammates and you are sure that they will always have your back.
One of the best companies you can work for to improve and learn, they allow you to push your limits.
You can always find the opportunity to change your career and consider a new position.
You have unlimited resources if you want to learn
cons:
I've been working here for 10 years and unfortunately it gets worse every year in terms of working hours and wages.
You will likely work harder than anyone you know.
It is not acceptable to be paid below the market, and a large part of employees who leave company are leaving because of this.
You work harder than all the other companies that are supported, but you have to constantly push to get paid yo deserved, this is really exhausting. I still don't understand why you can't get a raise regularly

pros: Great opportunity for new grads, they give you the tools to improve your skills with access to courses, funding for training etc, however it really falls on you to take the initiative, you will not grow unless you put yourself forward and make the effort. Anyone who is a recent grad should consider IBM as the first step in their career.
cons:
Confusing * arbitrary progression / compensation increase system. Management can be confusing as well as you have a "profile manager" who has influence over your career but they may not even work directly with you, as well as no clear job title changes etc, can be chaotic at times. 
IBM is also bad for allowing strong talent to leave due to the barriers to compensate them for what there value is. I've seen multiple extremely talented resources leave after 1 - 2 years to have a 30% increase at the next opportunity, often these people will return to IBM later with an even bigger increase. Seems to be a focus on hiring new talent vs retaining current talent.

2. When you will be asked to come to work location(Mostly Bangalore), you won't be provided accommodations(unlike the other companies). So this is a very sad part of the employment, it must provide accommodation for either 7 or 15 initial days of the employment, as the other companies do. Because imagine a person coming from a very remote place, where he/she will stay on the joining days.
3. It hits your confidence very hard when you see that people with equal qualifications earning far better than you and not only that, the people who are far less qualified than you in some another field earn much more than you.

pros:
I work at the Design Studio in Böblingen, Germany and I mainly wanted to join because I knew already how great the design community in Böblingen is. There is so much to say but in summary: I feel I got welcomed in a big family, work and private life is integrated and well balanced and I feel like I have found friends for life within the doors of the studio.

The design culture is lived and celebrated every day through different activities. It's implicit to say that I work with the best designers in here, some of these people have won multiple design awards with their work for IBM.

Not only locally but globally design plays a big role in the company. IBM is the second firm globally (after Google) with the most employed designers. So it's safe to say that there's a lot to learn and a lot of people to learn from. New hires are taken care of and have to go through a 6-week-bootcamp called Patterns which is like a training that will give you all the right tools to start in the new job.

IBM has even its own established Enterprise Design Thinking and that says already everything.

The tech topics are complex but challenging. Your colleagues are there to help you though!
cons: None! So far an amazing place to work. Of course you have to like the corporate environment.

pros: Working at IBM is good. Good clients and higher management.

review_title: A company you can grow in
pros: There are many learning resources in different industry domain. You can build growth mindset in the learning process. And you have access to many different project types.

review_title: IBM: One of the greatest place to work and to develop yourself both personally and professionally
pros:
Trust and personal responsibility in all relationships. - This is one of the three values IBM has and I could say I relate the most with this one. Since I joined IBM back in 2011, I had the opportunity to meet such great people to work with, co-workers and leaders that helped me to continuously learn new things and to develop myself in both personal and career life. They were always transparent and dedicated to every client`s success, to every project`s delivery, to every employee`s professional growth. This is what IBM means to me, here is where I found my second family 11 years ago and every single day it`s a pleasure for me to turn on my laptop to start working and this is not a joke :-)
I have never felt stress or pressure, I have always worked with love, dedication and relaxation and I could honestly say that you`ll find here a wonderful work environment, flexibility and understanding in everything you would need. I would recommend IBM to everyone over and over again without any hesitation!
cons: I saw this is a mandatory field but I really couldn`t find anything to put in here. I don`t think I have any Cons at this moment to share with you. For me, at least, this has been nothing but a great journey and it still is :-)

Lots of in-house learning opportunities, partnerships with learning companies and even (within budget) paid learning outside the IBM.
One doesn't have any excuse not to grow and maintain self relevant.
Diversity and inclusion for all ages, races, genders, orientations is one of the most recognized qualities in the globe.

Constant and close communication with management, even CEO on the strategy and transparency on results and outcomes.
Incentives for innovations, making ourselves better professionals, friendly competitions and initiatives all the time - even hard to keep up!
Always recognizing employees some way and incentivizing people to recognize peers as well.
Many areas with flexible hours and respect for family time. If you show you are worthy of trust, you can have a good worklife balance.
Ever growing company with opportunity for a stable and happy career.
cons:
Still some areas work in old-school ways, which goes against agility and time to market.
Career progression can be slow, given it's a giant company.

review_title: IF YOUR THINKING OF APPLYING OR ACCEPTING A ROLE, PLEASE STOP
job_title: Data Engineer in Baton Rouge, LA
pros: you get to meet people outside of the CIC and work on really cool projects with IBM Core
cons:
Everything about the Baton Rouge CIC is a CON. It’s a cult environment and if you don’t have a specific clique or don’t kiss behind, you’ll never make it. When you start they will tell you it’s an “open door policy” work place and that it’s okay to share your concerns with your peers, well that was a lie. Your salary is super low! I finished the apprenticeship at $42,500 and when switched over to a band 6g(associate) I never received a raise. Mangers hate talking about raises too! I was at 42,500 for almost two years and got a not to so great end of the year review in 2022, despite me doing everything in the gbs progression chart for a raise to band 7a! The center and managers do what they want to keep your salary low. It’ll take you 3-4 years to get to $55,000 when the Monroe center starts at $55,000. Cost of living is higher in Baton Rouge. The people who work at the center as associates can barely afford to pay for rent anywhere in a safe neighborhood in Baton Rouge.  I have ADHD, anxiety and depression and was put on a PIP to “give me structure”, mind you I never agreed or signed this PIP.  July I was fired because of non completion of the PIP but on May 26 my managers congratulated me for completing the PIP and the evidence of completion was posted in a box folder for my managers and Delivery Managers to see. There needs to be more management, disability, and diversity training. In June there was a new hire, she was my onboard buddy I was assigned, well little did I know she was replacing my spot on the team lol. My two years at IBM I had over 1,500 learning hours, I knew my role as a data engineer but my managers failed me. How can I be a data Engineer but my managers are project managers that have only used sql or no technical languages at all🫤.  I created training for my team so that we learn together, I participated in hackathons on behalf of IBM, I participated in service corps twice! 
During Hurricane Ida last year, I was homeless for 2 weeks! But I was still expected to show up for work and keep in touch with my client for the project I was on, I had no basic needs to even focus on my project.  If your neurodiverse please reach out to someone in HR- not BR HR and get accommodations. My managers joked about about me having adhd in my checkpoint goals. When I asked my manager about reasonable accommodations her response was “idk anything reasonable accommodations”. Also, if you’re traveling please get your manager to help you to expense your charges. I asked my managers over 10 times and they never helped me to expense. This was my first corporate job and we were never shown how to expense our credit card charges. I now I have an Amex bill for $3k because I traveled for IBM for a client project and no one helped me to expense it. Also, the apprenticeship is a waste of time, it’s just a way for IBM CIC to get FREE or CHEAP labor, because they don’t teach you anything technical while in the apprenticeship!  You have to fight to learn yourself. IBM CIC is backwards and I wouldn’t send my dog to them. Before I was terminated my manager asked me to resign. I was told by my manager that I would get 4 weeks pay, benefits, vacation days and sick days paid out(110 hours), he told me “I don’t write checks I can’t cash” apparently the check bounced. The next week I went on vacation because I had not had an actual vacation since December 2020. My first vacation in July 2022 really made everyone upset. When I came back from vacation my managers had a problem with every single thing I was doing. I spoke with my therapist and she asked me to take a FMLA mental health leave so I did, because the CIC had me in a dark place. I told my managers and she was upset and had an attitude, so I told her I would cancel my leave. My manager responded and told me to get documentation from my doctor that I was able to return to work. The next day, the first day of FMLA leave(because I hadn’t canceled yet, due to me getting a doctors note) I was fired due to “non-completion of PIP) which is a lie because I have documentation of every conversation held between my managers and I. Worst of all, when I was terminated my manager said I would get 4 weeks pay and package. By Friday of that week my benefits had been canceled and my final paycheck was July 15. I was given a payment for vacation but they cut me short I received $300, which doesn’t add up because I had 15 vacation days, I only used 5 days of vacation. I was never paid for the 10 unused days. Also, stop sending associates into the office when it not necessary! Just to say you have bodies in the building. Stop using your people as goods and trades! Jesus Christ. There is so much more I can go on about but I've typed the gist of things. 

Please stay away from this center! Please! It’s not good for anyones health unless you’re a white male! I don’t ever want anyone to experience what I did. I was gaslighted and put on a strict military type work flow, micromanaged and targeted. My mental health went from cheery to having second guests about my life. I was mentally beaten even after being a top performer. This center doesn’t care if you’re in your death bed, please stay away. This is my truth and I don't want anyone to go through it. Please be safe if you do decide to accept a position here.
